THE SCIONS OF SHANNARA, by Terry Brooks. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $19.95.) The adventures of two brothers who practice magic in a fantasy land where its use is forbidden.

BITTER SWEET by LaVyrie Spencer. (Putnam, $18.95.) A widow's ordeal after meeting her high school flame, now a less than happily married man.

VINELAND, by Thomas Pynchon (Little, Brown ($19.95.) The passions of the 1960's continue to rule the lives of members of a community in Northern California.

HOLLYWOOD, by Gore Vidal. (Random House, $19.95.) A docudrama of the 1920's, featuring Caroline Sanford, Washington newspaper publisher turned film star.
DADDY, by Danielle Steel (Delacorte, $19.95.) Unexpected crises wreck the safe, predictable world a man has built for himself and his family.
COLD HARBOUR, by Jack Higgins (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) The O.S.S. agent Craig Osbourne on a perilous mission during World War II.
THE GREAT AND SECRET SHOW, by Clive Barker. (Harper & Row, $19.95.) The mail he reads in a dead-letter office engages a man in a cosmic struggle both barbaric and baroque.
TALES FROM MARGARITAVILLE, by Jimmy Buffett (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $16.95.) Short stories set on a mythical Caribbean island.

WHAT I SAW AT THE REVOLUTION, by Peggy Noonan. (Random House, $19.95.) The memoirs of a speechwriter for Ronald Reagan and George Bush.

THE SECOND WORLD WAR, by John Keegan. (Viking, $29.95.) A military history.
THE CUCKOO'S EGG, by Clifford Stoll. (Doubleday, $19.95.) An astrophysicist tells how he stalked a computer hacker from California across America to West Germany.
THE TEMPTING OF AMERICA, by Robert M. Bork (Free Press, $22.50.) A critique of the relationship between politics and the law by Ronald Reagan's Supreme Court nominee.
PARTING WITH ILLUSIONS, by Vladimir Pozner. (Atlantic Monthly, $19.95.) The autobiography of a man raised in New York, who became a commentator for Radio Moscow.
THE EMPEROR'S NEW MIND, by Roger Penrose (Oxford University, $24.95.) A physicist maintains that computers will never replace human thinking.
A BRIEF HISTORY OF TIME, by Stephen W. Hawking (Bantam, $18.95.) A scientist views efforts to create a unified theory of the universe.
WHO NEEDS GOD, by Harold Kushner (Summit, $18.95.) A rabbi tells how religious commitment can make great differences in our lives.
AMONG SCHOOLCHILDREN, by Tracy Kidder (Todd/Houghton/Mifflin, $19.95.) A year in the life of a fifth-grade schoolteacher in Holyoke, Mass.
LOVE'S EXECUTIONER, by Irvin D. Yalom. (Basic, $19.95.) Case histories from a Stamford psychiatrist's files.

And Bear in Mind
(Editor's choices of other recent books of particular interest.)

LONDON FIELDS, by Martin Amis. (Harmony, $19.95.) Set in the grimmest of possible worlds, (London in 1999, where a global catastrophe - called just "the Crisis" - impends. Mr. Amis's novel pursues its vivid characters through a rich and complicated picaresque tale of destruction and self-destruction.
FIRE & ICE: The Greenhouse Effect, Ozone Depletion and Nuclear Winter, by David E. Fisher. (Harper & Row, $19.95.)

THE NEXT ONE HUNDRED YEARS: Shaping the Fate of Our Living Earth, by Jonathan Weinter. (Bantam, $19.95.) There is, both authors assure us, a scientific consensus about global warming: it's coming. But something can be done, they believe, and these studies passionately and credibly urge attention to a threatening future that many of us seem to have despaired of in advance.
AFTERLIFE, by Paul Monette (Crown, $19.95.) A gallant, painful novel that concerns three "AIDS widowers" trying to reconstruct lives tenuously held in the wake of their lovers' deaths.

THE PARIS REVIEW ANTHOLOGY, edited by George Plimpton (Norton, $25.) THE WRITER'S CHAPBOOK: A Compendium of Fact, Opinion, Wit, and Advice from the 20th Century's Preeminent Writers, edited by George Plimpton (Viking, $19.95.) Much has changed since Mr. Plimpton conceived The Paris Review in 1952, and these volumes - the first in a collection of writing from the magazine, the second compendium from its interviews - are handy, entertaining and high-spirited guides to the last four decades by the engineers of change themselves.

THE QUINCUNX, by Charles Palliser. (Ballantine, $25.) Can you imagine a gigantic (788 pages) imitation of Dickens, abounding in wickedness, full of descriptive power, replete with plot and gratifyingly hard to put down? Mr. Palliser did!
